text: Okay the October 11, 2021 meeting of the Seattle city Council has come to order.
Wilbur clerk please?
[roll being called] nine present.
Thank you so much presentations I am not aware of presentations for the day so I moved to approval of the minutes.

-- have been reviewed--hearing no objection the minutes are being signed will the clerk please affix my signature to the minutes if there is no objection the introduction a referral calendar will be adopted.
Hearing no objection, it is adopted.
If there is no objection the agenda will be adopted.
Hearing no agenda objection the agenda is adopted.

We will open for a public comment period for items on the--I want to thank everyone for their ongoing patience as we continue to operate--it remains our strong intent to continue to have public comment at all of our Council meetings.
And as a reminder the city council does--I will moderate the public comment period in the following manner public comment period today is--and using the meeting phone number I.D.
And Passcode that was Emailed to them--this is different from the general meeting listen line Call-In information.
-- you can sign up before the end of public comment by going to our Website.

Public comment link is also listed on today's agenda once I call your name staff will Unmute you, you will hear the prompt that you have been Unmute it and that will be your Cue to press Á6 and then begin speaking please begin by saying your name the item you are addressing and your comment should relate to an item on today's agenda the introduction a referral calendar or--you are going to hear a Chime in about 10 seconds--wrapping up your public comment if you do not and your comments at that allotted time then your microphone is going to be muted so we can call on the next Speaker.

Once you have concluded your public comment we ask that you Disconnect from the line and--or one of the listening options listed on the agenda, public comment period is now open we will now start with the first Speaker after you hear the prompt that you have been Unmute it, please remember to press Á6 in order to Unmute yourself.
First Speaker is Howard Gail and then we will hear from Daniel Cavanaugh.
Good afternoon Howard Gail district 7 speaking on--around one third of police officers remain Unvaccinated.

-- that is over five times as many as were killed by gunfire knife and assault combined so police can kill a person because of an imaginary fear but they refused to protect themselves and the public from a very real and very deadly fear.

This makes clear that police culture is so imbued with irrational fear and bias that policy and training will have very little effect on it, there is only accountability--Councilmembers will have to face the consequences of the bullying antisocial--since the start of Federal oversight nearly a decade ago, that severely--it allowed SPD officers to escape accountability guaranteeing a repeat, these are the consequences of failed accountability, now Councilmembers having escaped all of these consequences must face this bullying antisocial and transients head on and--as a clear expression of underlying extreme right wing beliefs and bias.
Spd officers ruined you of this in 2020 when they many of whom are--the only Union--please give us full civilian community control of police, go to--to find out how . that is Seattle Stop.Org.
Next up is Daniel Cavanaugh followed by Logan's one

-- I am an Organizer with--calling to support--I am calling on you to stand with construction workers in Seattle--by voting in support of--carpenters and other construction workers are required to--but often have to pay $100 or more a week in parking.
-- I have been working in food service for most of my life, and the one time but I did work downtown I got paid parking as someone who worked in a small bakery.

If a small bakery can afford it, then these construction corporations who are making millions of dollars every year can absolutely afford it when it is not an option to take public transit for these construction workers.

And most construction workers are forced to drive in and park from outside of Seattle because they cannot afford to live in the building and--that is because the cost of living is so high with the--this is something that the workers are demanding and I really urge Councilmembers to support--I do not want to hear any excuses about--the council must stand with construction workers and not with their millionaire bosses.
Next is Logan swan followed by Sonja--Logan you are still muted so please remember to press Á6.
There you go.
Go ahead.

My name is Logan swan--I am calling to support--some of you said that you support their sisters and Brothers in the carpentry community while they are on strike--this is a primary demand from the rank-and-file--the issue of parking should be handled through legislation here is your chance to walk the walk.
-- we are demanding that the employers--cover that cost rather than being--to require the bosses pay this cost of doing business rather than my sisters and brothers have to pay just to go to work.
Next is Sonja and then we will hear from Jordan.

I am a working mom in district 3 and a landlord and I am calling in support of the bill put forward by Councilmember Sawant .--workers cannot even live in Seattle because the average home price is now over $800,000 or $2300 a month in rent.

-- the buses do not even operate--I never knew that construction workers had to pay for parking because they are the ones building our city I thought they could park anywhere they wanted and needed to, but the strike by the brave carpenters and workers is really highlighting--I am asking you to pass this legislation without loopholes--the U.S. Billionaires have gotten $1.8 trillion richer, and globally Billionaires are 10.2 trillion dollars richer than they were at the start of this pandemic.
The proposed 2022 budget is completely unacceptable.
-- as an activist with--and I really hope we can work together and push the city Council to increase the Amazon tax by $120 million--and could we please fund public showers and bathrooms --
Next is Jordan followed by Nicholas.
Can you hear me?

Great, my name is Jordan Quinn, I am a Renter in district 2. I am also an activist with the people's budget movement and I support--calling to urge the Democratic Councilmembers to join Councilmember Sawant to fight for--I signed a petition with over 1000 Union and Nonunion workers--this should also focus on--but paying for your employees parking should be a basic--then you can absolutely afford to pay for parking, the thousands of workers who are actually doing the work every day but cannot afford to work here.
So please pass this legislation--thanks.
Thank you, next is Nicholas followed by Kevin.

My name is Nicholas and I am another community member calling in support of the bill put forward by Councilmember Sawant to make construction bosses pay 100% of parking costs for all construction workers on job sites.

-- carpenters and other construction workers are required to drive to job sites with vehicles loaded with tools Harnesses and other equipment but often have to pay $100 or more per week--that works out to thousands of dollars a year that construction workers have to pay just to work here.
Construction workers have to drive there.
They have a lot of equipment as I already mentioned--before public transit is even available to them.

Most construction workers are forced to drive in from outside of the city of Seattle because they cannot afford to live in the buildings that they themselves are building because the--Averagehome prices are over $800,000 in Seattle and over $2300 in rent for a single bedroom apartment.
-- it should be passed to protect workers in the city of Seattle.
Please pass this legislation.
-- thank you.
Next up is Kevin followed by Nina.
My name is Kevin and I am a Seattle education Association member.

-- I am calling for you to stand in solidarity with construction workers in Seattle and vote in support of--carpenters and other construction workers have paid a lot each week and that amounts to a tax of thousands of dollars a year just to go to work.

Most construction workers cannot afford to live here,--the cost of living is so high in Seattle, especially with the low amounts of affordable housing that we have and the sky high rents they keep going up during the pandemic.
-- I am urging you as city Councilmembers to immediately pass Councilmember Sawant's legislation--thank you.
Thank you, next is Nina, followed by Peter Donahue.
My name is Nina, I am a carpenter out of local 30 I am a Renter I live in district 2.
And I am here to push Councilmember Sawant's legislation to pay for the contractors to 100% fully pay our, parking.

A lot of my brothers and sisters on the job are paying upwards of $500 a month which is money that should be going to spending time with their families, and as they spend even less time with their families because they spend so much time on the road as it is because they are forced to drive in our horrific traffic, so at least you Democrats who say that you are Prolabor can do is make sure that they do not have to pay an extra $500 per month out of their own pocket just to go to work.

This will help the carpenters who are in the middle of a strike, this will help Nonunion workers who are stuck paying these costs with their lower wages--we need to help Nonunion people if we are Prolabor, which I heard from Democrats that they say that they are Prolabor but I would like to see it with my own eyes.
This will help all of the people who cannot afford to live in the city that they built.

This will take it off of our bargaining committee's plate, we are struggling as it is to ask for the wages that we deserve, and we cannot even pay for parking, so this will free up the committee to actually hopefully ask for the wages that we rightfully are owed.
Next is Peter Donahue followed by Shirley Henderson.
-- the parking is too high, the commutes are ridiculous.
-- I have lived here a long time and--I would like to thank Councilmember Strauss and Councilmember Sawant for walking up the line with the carpenters.
I appreciate your leadership and I asked the rest of the Council members to step up and show some leadership as well.
The union leadership is struggling.
We really need your help and solidarity --
Next up is Shirley Henderson followed by David Haynes.

-- my name is Shirley and I am a small business planner and I am very familiar with--which is why I am calling in with my sisters and Brothers in support of the bill put forward by Councilmember Sawant to make construction contractor boxes fully paid 100% of all--on Seattle job sites.
I am calling on you Councilmembers to stand with construction workers in Seattle, not just with the bosses by voting in support of the basic needs of thousands of workers to build our city.
-- most construction workers are forced as others have said to commute long distances because they cannot afford to live in the buildings they are holding in this city.
As others have highlighted it is because the cost of living is so high in this city especially with the lack of affordable housing and skyrocketing rent.

Rents have risen more than 25% since the start of this year alone and--this is yet another reason why we need to expand the Amazon tax--it is a No-Brainer and has huge support from construction workers and community members, and I want to echo what Sonja said earlier, I had no idea that construction workers had to pay for parking, it is absurd and--hundreds of these signatures have come from--to talk with other workers and community organizers.
I urge you to immediately pass the legislation to require all --
Next is David followed by Gabriel.
Thank you.
I live in district 7 at first and Cherry street.
There is a crack war Meth war and heroin sex crime war being conducted in my neighborhood and the police chief refuses to help.
He is going around blaming the homeless for all the crime for an easier payday while only sweeping the tents, never the criminals into a proper Jailhouse.

He is going around blaming the city hall it is obvious--hiring an unqualified racist cowardice police chief--endangering society while counsel is refusing to investigate the six-figure salary service providers--who donate tax money meant to solve the homeless crisis to counsel and the activist and community organizers paid to saturate the public comment Intimidating counsel to keep giving corrupt races Nonprofits money or else get protested in a--with a priority for criminals in motels with no community service officer--with actual qualified nonprofit Soffit nonprofit service providers.
-- they are not bothering people in the neighborhood and they might be the wrong skin color.

We need a federal investigation of the office of housing for ensuring an oppressive races Backstabbed on--is given to 200 people or so for delivery services while so-called community safety is another by off of protesters using money for criminals --
Next is Gabriel followed by Arthur.
Gabriel you are still muted so press Á6 and we can hear you.
We had you and then you went away try one more time Á6.
There you go.

My name is Gabriel I am a Renter in district 3 and I am calling to urge the Councilmembers to support Councilmember Sawant's people's budget as well as--I was totally surprised at the fact that construction workers do not already receive free parking.

They are literally building the city and they do not get paid enough to live here and to add insult to injury we make them pay for their parking on top of--as a Tech worker I can get on my computer and work from home but the fact that we are making--is just a clear example of oppressive cost that working people have to play to pay.
-- we absolutely need to expand the Amazon tax--thank you.

My name is Arthur, I am the chair of--we are the largest--of carpenters in the Pacific Northwest we are also the--local 30 carpenters, I wanted to speak in support of Councilmember Sawant's bill to get all construction workers paid parking.

I currently do not live in Seattle, I cannot afford to live in Seattle, I live in Everett, and many hundreds and hundreds of construction workers like myself cannot afford to live in Seattle and we commute daily to go to Seattle to build the city that many of you all take for granted.

Quite often construction workers leave way before dawn, like about 3 to 4 a.m., it is quite common, when you are all still asleep, and when we get to town and we have to pay for parking all day, the parking rates have gone up astronomically in the last decade because they have also gone up in conjunction with the price of real estate.
And the parking lots are going away in Seattle because of all the High-Rises and different buildings that we build, the parking just continues to rise.
It is really not a burden that should fall on the shoulders of construction workers, it is only right that our bosses and contractors pay, please support this bill, thank you.
Thank you.
I am showing the last two speakers are registered but not present, that is William and Aiden, and I am looking to our I.T.
Post to make sure no one is in the waiting room who is Preregistered and ready to go.
There are no other public comment registrants.

With that being said we are going to go ahead and close out the period of public comment and move to other items of business on the agenda we do have a short agenda this afternoon so we will go ahead and get going, the first item is the payment of the bills will the clerk please read the title?
I moved to Cass past Council bill 120187--will the clerk please call the roll on the passage of the bill?
[roll being called] eight in favor, none opposed.
The bill passes and the chair will sign it, will the clerk please affix my signature to the legislation on my behalf?
Will the clerk please read item number 1 into the record?

Council bill 120186: an ordinance relating to city employment; authorizing the execution of agreements between the city of Seattle and certain city unions; authorizing Compnsation for certain city employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement; and ratifying and confirming certain prior acts.
I moved to pass Council bill 120186, is there a second?

It has been moved and Seconded to pass the bill, I am the sponsor of this bill so I will address it first, and then open the floor to comments, but before we actually debate the underlying bill, I did want to move the adoption of the amendment, I did have an opportunity to speak about the amendment this morning and it was published on the agenda it is amendment A. we will do that first so we have the conversation of a potentially amended bill before us.
-- is there a second?

It has been moved and Seconded to amend the bill as presented on amendment A. as I described during this counsel briefing--this agreement is ready now to be attached to this legislation now that those negotiations have occurred and been completed.
I am happy to answer any questions about amendment A. of course I do recommend that my colleagues support the option of amendment A. any questions?
Or comments on amendment a? C none, will the clerk please call the roll on the adoption of amendment a?
[roll being called] nine in favor, none opposed.
The motion carries an amendment a is adopted.
And I am going to go ahead and make comments on the amended bill before opening it up to any further debate.

Council bill 120186 as amended includes terms for front-line worker pay that are authorized by this Council bill--so the terms in this bill were negotiated with various unions representing various--and the benefits therein will apply to both representative and Nonrepresentative front-line workers employed by all three branches of state government including the legislative branch.

Following the adoption of amendment a which we just did this--all the bargaining units who have agreed to these terms this front-line worker pay will go to eligible employees in the form of a lump sum payment of up to a maximum of $1750.

This is comparable to the total value of the Telework Stipends that have been--generally speaking city workers are eligible for either the Telework Stipend or the Front- line worker pay and cannot earn both benefits.

The estimated cost for additional pay to representative and Non- representative front-line workers is approximately $6.5 million and there are--to support this additional expense I do want to make sure that members of the viewing public and colleagues know that future legislation will have to come before the Council later this year or early next year to make appropriations to various city departments in order for them to execute the lump sum payments to eligible employees once we have a better sense of the full universe of those who are claiming.
Finally as I noted during the Council breathing briefing--with the exception of the Seattle police officers Guild.
The Seattle police officers Guild was offered the same terms and benefits but has so far rejected the proposed terms.

We are disappointed in that rejection, but we will continue to move through our process is here to ensure that the Front- line workers who are complying with vaccine requirements and who are also front-line workers in agreeing to accept these terms are compensated accordingly.
Okay, I do not have anything else to say on this particular issue so I am going to go ahead and wrap up my comments and open up the floor to any additional comments on Council bill 120186.
Any additional comments or questions?
I just want to make one additional point thank you Council President Gonzalez for covering this so thoroughly.

One additional point I would just like to add is my understanding as it relates to--that the city did not--to offers on vaccine mandates so I think that is an important clarification for folks who are following along on both of these related issues, thank you.
Thank you.
Any other comments or questions on Council bill 120186 as amended?
Hearing none, will the clerk please call the roll on the passage of the amended bill?
[roll being called] nine in favor, none opposed.
The motion carries the bill passes as amended and the chair will sign it will the clerk please affix my signature to the legislation on my behalf?
Is there any further business to come before the Council?
Not seeing any hands raised so this does conclude the items of business on today's agenda the next regularly scheduled city council meeting is on October 18 2021 at 2:00 P.M.
I hope you have a wonderful afternoon we are adjourned thanks everyone.
